Sentence: The chief of BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.
After Record Profit, Chief Says He’ll Leave

Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.
After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
Shares of Alcoa rose in premarket trading Tuesday after The Times of London reported that two British-Australian mining giants were considering buying the aluminum producer.

The paper said that BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto have begun examining the possibilities of a $40 billion buyout of the Pittsburgh-based company, while Alcoa has separately drawn up a list of chief executive candidates.
Report Stokes Speculation About Alcoa Takeover

Speculation that mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto are both circling U.S. aluminum producer Alcoa has, unsurprisingly, turned industry watchers’ attention to other possible takeover targets in the industry.
Takeover Speculation Heats Up Aluminum Sector
BHP Billiton once considered a possible suitor for Alcoa, which began a hostile bid of its own for Alcan, may become a target itself.
Could BHP Be the First $120 Billion Buyout Target?

Days after an analyst’s report suggested that BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, could become a target for private equity buyers, speculation surfaced that the company is considering a bid for a rival, the Rio Tinto Group.
Rumors of BHP Bid for Rio Tinto Send Shares Soaring
The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan rejected a $27.4 billion hostile bid from a rival, Alcoa, on Tuesday, calling the offer inadequate.

Alcan said that it was in talks with other companies — The Globe and Mail newspaper reported that one of them is the Australian mining giant BHP Billiton — and added that it was considering the possibility of turning the tables with a counterbid for Alcoa.
Alcan Spurns Hostile Bid and Talks to White Knights

BHP Billiton, the mining company, chose the head of its copper and aluminum division, Marius Kloppers, to succeed its American chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, when Mr. Goodyear steps down Oct. 1.
Mr. Goodyear has overseen a wave of record-setting earnings since taking charge of the company in 2003 as the company benefited from a China-led boom in demand for iron and other metals.
But in the last two years, soaring prices for copper have fueled BHP’s results.
Mr. Kloppers, a 44-year-old South African, played a crucial role in BHP’s merger with Billiton in 2001 and in the $7.6 billion takeover of WMC Resources in 2005.
BHP Billiton Selects a Chief Executive

BHP Billiton, the mining company, chose the head of its copper and aluminum division, Marius Kloppers, to succeed its American chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, when Mr. Goodyear steps down Oct. 1.

BHP Billiton, the world’s largest mining company, has revived plans for a $40 billion (£20.2 billion) takeover of Alcoa, according to The Times of London.
The newspaper, without citing any named sources, said BHP is in the early stages of evaluating the merits of a takeover.
BHP, based in Melbourne, “is not thought to have” formally approached Alcoa, the Times reported.
